title: Hotdog-Sandwich Unification Framework

prerequisites: Identify and invite key stakeholder representatives (e.g. sandwich purists, hotdog traditionalists, culinary professionals, linguistic scholars, consumer advocates)
steps.outcome: A legitimate, authoritative body to define food classification standards
risks: Difficulty achieving consensus among diverse stakeholders
Perceptions of bias or lack of inclusivity

prerequisites: Analyze structural, cultural, and practical factors
Establish criteria for both sandwich and hotdog designations
steps.outcome: A framework that recognizes both sandwich and hotdog as valid food categories
risks: Pushback from hardline purists on either side
Confusion over boundary cases and transitional foods

prerequisites: Define clear labeling and menu standards
Educate consumers on new classification system
steps.outcome: Peaceful coexistence of sandwich and hotdog identities with clear operational guidelines
risks: Resistance to change and adoption of new standards
Ongoing debates and disputes despite new framework

steps.action: Expand the Framework to Other Food Taxonomies
prerequisites: Analyze lessons learned from Hotdog-Sandwich unification
Identify other contentious food classification issues
steps.outcome: A replicable model for resolving food taxonomy conflicts through inclusive, multi-stakeholder collaboration
risks: Scope creep and dilution of focus on core Hotdog-Sandwich issue
Resistance to applying the model to other food debates

resource_requirements: Funding for Hotdog-Sandwich Taxonomic Council operations
Expertise in food science, culinary arts, linguistics, and conflict resolution
Outreach and communication resources to engage stakeholders and educate the public
